question: Ya miss me, Weasel?
answer: You know my name -- it's Weisel. Mister Weisel to you. How many?

question: Don't rush me -- I'm perusin' * the mercandice... Mr. Weasel. * The Newsies love it as Jack deliberately takes a paper, turns and scans. Seeing Les staring at him, Jack winks. Les smiles back, fascinated. Jack turns back to Weasel with a fifty-cent piece. The usual. Weasel grabs for the coin -- Jack flips it out of his * grasp and onto the counter. The Newsies whoop.
answer: Hundred for the wiseguy -- next! *

question: scans the newspaper for a catchy headline; Race, Crutchy, the others wander up, doing the same. A commotion O.S. and they look up to see -- -- at the window, Weasel is in David's face. *
answer: Ya got ya papes -- move outta here. *

question: Cowboy! They call him Cowboy!
answer: That and a lotta other things -- including Jack Kelly, which is what my mudder called me. What do they call you, kid?

question: Les. This is David, he's my brother. He's older.
answer: No kiddin'. How old are you, Les?

question: Near ten.
answer: No good. Anybody asks, you're seven. Younger sells more papes, Les -- and if we're gonna be partners --

question: If he's the best, then why does he need us?
answer: I don't need you, pal. But I ain't * got a cute little brother to front * for me. And Les here... * ... With this kid's puss and my God-given talent, we can easy move a thousand papers a week. Whattaya say? Deal?

question: Gotta split fifty-fifty.
answer: Sixty-forty. Or I forget the whole t'ing. David reluctantly offers his hand. Jack spits in his palm and shakes. Les whoops and they move off, Jack already being the mentor -- The name of the game is volume, Dave. You only took twenty papes -- why?

question: Bad headline...?
answer: First t'ing you gotta learn -- headlines don't sell papes, newsies sell papes. We're what holds this town together -- without newsies, nobody knows nuttin'! They move away from Newsie Square as above them, the GOLDEN DOME OF THE WORLD BUILDING glistens in the morning sun.

question: 'Trolley Strike Drags On for Third Week' -- this so-called headline drags on for infinity!
answer: The news is slow, Chief, the Trolley Strike's all we got --

question: It's all Mr. William Randolph Hearst has, too -- see how he covers the strike! The magnifying glass swings to a copy of the New York Journal with a large black headline Hearst is killing us in the circulation war -- and you give me headlines that would put a whirling dervish to sleep! Steal Hearst's man -- offer him double what Hearst pays.
answer: That's how he stole him from us. Chief, you spend as much as you make fighting Hearst. That's why the paper's losing money --

question: I created the World to be the best and I'll spend whatever it takes to -- What is that deafening noise?
answer: Just the Newsies, Chief, I'll --

question: Never mind -- where was I? *
answer: Creating the World, Chief. *

question: You're a natural, kid. You remind me of me -- and I can't say greater than that.
answer: Extra, 'Trolley strike drags on!'

question: Nextry, nextry -- 'Ellis Island in flames -- big con-fla-gration!'
answer: What -- ? Where's that story -- ?

question: Page nine -- thank you, sir. Nextry, 'Thousands flee in panic -- '
answer: 'Trash fire near immigration building frightens seagulls -- ?'

question: The Refuge -- ?
answer: Sleeper!

question: I'm not crossing that! Anyway, I don't think they're chasing us --
answer: No? What're they doin' then?

question: I think they're chasing you! Snyder and MacSwain huff out onto the roof. David, still uncertain, looks back at them -- the runs across the plank. Jack calmly topples the plank to the street as the pursuers reach it, gasping for breath -- he gives Snyder a little salute, then moves on to a rooftop exit -- I want some answers -- Why was he chasing you? What's the Refuge?
answer: The Refuge is this jail for kids. That guy, Snyder, he's the warden.

question: I was starvin'. I stole some food.
answer: Right, food. He called you 'Sullivan' --

question: Yeah, food. My name's Kelly, Jack Kelly, like I told you. Think I'm lyin'?
answer: You have a way of 'improving the truth.' Why was he chasing you?

question: Nah. Teddy Roosevelt. Ever heard of him? David starts to reply when he sees something behind Jack * that makes his mouth drop open. At the top of a short * flight of stairs, a vision is frowning down at them, * speaking in a theatrical Swedish accent. *
answer: What is the meaning of this? No one is allowed backstage -- you will leave at once! Out, out, out, out --

question: You wouldn't kick me out without a kiss goodbye, wouldya, Medda? Surprised, she gasps in delight -- throwing her arms around Jack. David can't believe it. Medda's accent quickly disappears.
answer: Kelly, where've you been, kid? I miss you up in the balcony -- you know I sing all my songs to you.

question: This is David and Les. And this is the greatest star of the vaudeville stage today, Miss Medda Larkson, the Swedish Meadowlark.
answer: Welcome!

question: Medda also owns the joint.
answer: Don't ever own a theater, kid. Don't even think about it.

question: -- then that, multiplied by forty thousand papers a day, seven days a week -- well, it would pay some of the bills around here.
answer: Chief, if you do this, every Newsie we got will head straight for Hearst.

question: Not necessarily. As newspapermen, Hearst and I would cut each other's throats to get the best of the other. But as businessmen -- and gentlemen -- we often agree on ways to keep down certain operating costs. If I know Willie Hearst, he's going to wish he thought of this himself.
answer: What about the other papers -- ?

question: Awright, pipe down! Don't you see it's a gag? Just Weasel bein' a weasel. Joke's over, Wease. Gimme a hunnerd. He plops fifty cents on the counter. Weasel's grin gets weaselier as he slides it back.
answer: Hunnerd'll cost ya sixty, Cowboy.

question: I ain't payin' no sixty --
answer: Then move outta the way --

question: One thing for sure. If we don't sell papes, then nobody sells papes. Nobody comes through those gates 'til they put the price back where it was.
answer: You mean like a strike...?

question: Yeah, a strike -- good idea, Dave.
answer: No, I didn't mean -- we can't strike, we're not a union --

question: We go on strike, we're a union, right? Keep it comin', Dave --
answer: There's not enough of us -- maybe if we got every Newsie in New York --

question: Yeah, we organize -- we get all the New York Newsies to join us! This is great, Dave, keep talkin' --
answer: It's no joke! You saw what happened to those trolley workers --

question: Another great idea! Any Newsie don't join with us, we soak 'im -- just like the trolley workers!
answer: Nooo! Stop and think, willya? You can't just rush everybody into this!

question: Well, he don't make me nervous. You and me, Boots, we take Brooklyn. Dave can keep us company. Okay, Dave?
answer: Sure. Right after you take our demands to Pulitzer.

question: Me? To Pulitzer?
answer: You're the leader.

question: What's going on?
answer: They're going in to present our demands to Pulitzer.

question: What demands?
answer: The Newsies' demands. We're on strike. Denton looks around, a little amazed. He takes out a notebook.

question: I'm Denton, New York Sun. What's your name?
answer: David...

question: David. As in David and Goliath? You really think old man Pulitzer's going to listen to your demands?
answer: He has to.

question: You're right. Brains. But I got brains, too -- and more than half-a-one. How do I know you punks won't run the first time some goon comes atcha with a club? How do I know you're in it to win?
answer: 'Cause I'm tellin' you.

question: Not good enough, Jackie-boy. You gotta show me.
answer: Maybe you lost your guts, Spotty- boy -- -- or maybe you traded 'em to some chicken for that beak of yours. Maybe you gotta show me you ain't afraid to join the strike. Murder's in the air

question: Hey, whattaya hangin' around here for? That Dave up there? Hiya, Dave!
answer: Go get your hat, Crutch -- kiss Snyder good-bye.

question: Yeah... hey, shoulda seen me in court today -- old Judge Movealong Monahan hisself! Took him two minutes to move me along to Snyder for 'my own good.'
answer: Later, Crutchy -- get your stuff. Crutchy stops Jack's hand prying at the bars.

question: Listen, Jack... truth is, I ain't walkin' so good. Oscar and Morris kinda worked me over a little...
answer: They hurt you...? Don't worry, we'll carry you --

question: You mean it's true --? Crutchy hears something and quickly shushes them
answer: Crutchy won't last in there... I seen stronger guys than him not make it.

question: Did you really escape in Teddy Roosevelt's coach?
answer: Not in it. On it.

question: What was he doing at the Refuge?
answer: Runnin' for governor. Showin' his concern, like all pols during elections.

question: Teddy's not like other politicians. He's the biggest hero in the country.
answer: Anyway, he's there. I see his fancy coach waitin' for 'im, so I sneaks on top of it. Teddy gets in and he's wavin' goodbye, and all the guys are wavin' goodbye, and Snyder's wavin' -- 'Good-byeeee, Colonel Roosevelt!' So just as we're goin' out the gate, I stands up and -- 'Good-byeee, Warden Snyder!' It was in the papes and everything.

question: He's governor now. I don't understand how he could see that place and not do anything --
answer: He only seen what Snyder wanted him to -- good food, everything the city pays for that Snyder usually steals.

question: I'll bet if he just knew -- I mean, he's a hero --
answer: Last year he was a hero. This year he's a politician.

question: That's Jack -- ! Hey, he looks just like hisself! Snyder looks at the picture
answer: You know this boy...?

question: Him? Nah.
answer: You have a famous friend, this 'Jack.'... Do you know where he lives...?

question: Did you sleep there? Why didn't you wake us up?
answer: Didn't wanna disturb nobody... anyway, it's like the Waldorf out here... great view, cool air --

question: Go up on the roof. It's all getting so big. The family's very worried about the boys. And you, too.
answer: Your mom and pop are worried about me...?

question: The whole family... David says you're moving away when the strike's over. To Santa Fe. I've never been out of the city.
answer: You'd like it out there -- they got this big yellow desert and the air's real blue, see, from the sky, and the sun, it's bigger out there.

question: It's the same sun as here.
answer: No. No, it ain't... Not that I been there or nothin'.

question: Guess your parents wrote you about it. Bet you can't wait to see them again.
answer: Sure... big family reunion. Soon's I get the dough for train fare.

question: David said you spent all your money to rent the theater.
answer: Sounds like you and Dave don't do nothin' but talk about me.

question: We do not.
answer: Not that I blame you -- me bein' such an interestin' guy and all --

question: Are you...?
answer: What'd I tell ya -- interestin', right? Sarah giggles. The leaflet gyrates in the wind as we

question: You know Warden Snyder, don't you, Mayor? I believe you appointed him. The Mayor nods ruefully; not one of his best appoint- ments.
answer: If this boy is a fugitive, then the chief can quietly arrest him and --

question: Not quietly -- I want an example made. I want this rabble he's roused to see what happens to those who dare to -- well, they should see justice in action.
answer: Arrest him at the rally? But...

question: By the way, Mayor, I'm having a few friends for cards that night -- newspaper friends, Willie Hearst, Gordon Bennett. Perhaps you'll join us -- we can talk about the coming election.
answer: I'd be honored... thank you. Pulitzer dismisses them and they start out, Snyder oozing backwards, the Mayor now all business with Chief Devery. Chief, when you arrest this Kelly, you'd better go in force -- in case some of his misguided friends should start any trouble. As they go, Pulitzer picks up his magnifying glass and examines the leaflet. We CUT AWAY as he stares through the glass so he seems to be looking at --

question: Any of you represented by counsel? No? Good. That'll move things along considerably. David sees Denton come in, a neat bandage on his head.
answer: Judge Movealong, ya honor, I object.

question: On what grounds?
answer: On the grounds of Brooklyn, ya honor! The Newsies congratulate Spot. Monahan gavels.

question: This boy's real name is Francis Sullivan; mother deceased; father a convict in the state penitentiary -- He is currently an escapee from the House of Refuge, where his original sentence of three months for theft was extended six months for disruptive behavior --
answer: -- Like demandin' you give us the food you steal from us --

question: -- Followed by an additional six months for an attempted escape --
answer: -- Last time wasn't no attempt, remember, Snyder? Me and Teddy Roosevelt wavin' bye-bye --

question: -- Therefore, I ask that he be returned to the House of Refuge --
answer: -- For my own good, right, Movealong? -- and for what Snyder kicks back to ya --

question: Why didn't The Sun print the story?
answer: Because it never happened. If it's not in the papers, then it never happened. The owners decreed that it not be in the papers, therefore... I just came to tell you fellows goodbye. They exchange puzzled looks. David sees Denton's expression.

question: Denton, what's happened -- you get fired or somethin'?
answer: Reassigned -- back to my old job as The Sun's ace war correspondent. The owner thinks I should be covering only the 'really important' stories. So wish me luck, boys. At least half what I wish you. They don't always fire you, David. He moves off; David, stunned, hurries after him.

question: They bought you off... didn't they? Didn't they!
answer: They could've blackballed me from every paper in the country. I'm a newspaperman, I have to have a paper to write for. He looks at David; hurt, betrayed, angry; wishes there was more he could say. He hands him something from his coat. This is the story I wrote about the rally. I want you to read it at least. He hands it to David and goes. David returns to the others, angrily crumpling the story and hurling it onto the table. The boys look puzzled; Les, still eating the sausage, picks up the story and looks at it curiously.

question: Very impressive. So where do they keep the trains in this station? Seitz shows him into an elegant library. Snyder tries to follow but Seitz stops him, closing the doors. Inside, Jack looks around to see the imposing figure of Pulitzer staring at him, framed by luxurious furnishings. For a moment, the two just stare at each other. Then -- Sorry to see you ain't doin' so good, Joe. *
answer: Know what I was doing when I was your age? I was in a war. The Civil War.

question: I heard of it. You win?
answer: People think wars are about right and wrong. They're not. They're about power. You know what power is?

question: Heard of that, too. I don't just sell ya papes, Joe. Sometimes I read 'em. Pulitzer ignores the impudence, continues quietly.
answer: Power means that I could see to it that you serve your full sentence at the Refuge. Or I could pull strings and have you free tomorrow. It means I could give you my pocket change -- and you'd have more money than you'd likely ever earn.

question: You bribin' me, Joe? Thanks for the compliment, but I ain't got the power to stop the strike --
answer: I disagree. You're the spirit of the strike, without you, they'd fall apart in a few days.

question: Ring for my coach, willya? It's past my bedtime --
answer: Shut your mouth and listen ! You're going to do exactly as I say --

question: -- or what? You'll send me back to the Refuge? I'll bust out again --
answer: -- and be a fugitive who's pursued and caught and returned. I'm offering you a choice -- is that what you choose?

question: I told ya... I can't call off the strike.
answer: I'm not asking you to. All I ask is that you return to your old job -- as Newsie for the The World.

question: And be a scab? Forget it --
answer: For a few days. Then the strike ends -- and it will end, boy, make no mistake -- and you can go wherever you want to buy a ticket. Free and clear, with money in your pocket... and no one chasing you. Jack is silent, troubled. Pulitzer pushes a buzzer. You go back to the Refuge. Think it over in your cell. Let me know in the morning.

question: Why're you stoppin' -- we've got to run!
answer: You shouldn't'a done this, David. They could put you in jail --

question: It's worth it -- let's go --
answer: You go to jail, what happens to your family? You don't know nothin' about jail! Thanks for what you done, but you gotta get outta here --

question: I don't understand --
answer: I don't either -- I don't understand nothin' no more! Jack pushes David down the street. Just go!

question: I don't either -- I don't understand nothin' no more! Jack pushes David down the street. Just go!
answer: Snitched it offa Snyder's plate when I was servin' him -- the biggest one! Snyder was eatin' good tonight -- the stuff we don't never get? * Patatas... olives... ... liver and bacon. Sauerkraut... Guess what I done to his sauerkraut.

question: So what's it git'cha?
answer: Anudder three months, prob'ly. But you can't let 'em beat'cha, right, Jack?

question: Couldn't stay away, huh. *
answer: Guess I can't be somethin' I ain't.

question: A scab...? *
answer: Nah. Smart. *

question: Without you, the strike's falling apart...
answer: I got no choice. I stay here, they lock me up 'til I'm twenty- one.

question: You're not going to run away. They'll just come after you. You have to fight them.
answer: They got it all wrapped up, Sarah and nothin' I can do is gonna make one bit of difference.

question: You're wrong. You touched people you don't even know about. She removes the stained pages from her shawl. Denton's story.
answer: Denton looked out for hisself just like I gotta do -- so save it.

question: Keep reading. Can these words really be about him...? As we GO TO --
answer: ' -- And that is what terrifies the powers-that-be, for they know our city thrives on the shame of child labor. Therefore, Jack Kelly's voice must be stopped, whatever the cost... Damn good writing, isn't it?

question: All them sweatshop kids are listenin' to me...?
answer: They think if the Newsies can do it, why can't they? All they need is a leader.

question: The minute I show my face, I'm back in the Refuge.
answer: You'd have help this time. I've been investigating the Refuge -- I know somebody who's going to be very interested in Snyder's little racket.

question: You're going to listen to me, boy --
answer: I'd like to, Joe -- -- but I can't hear ya.

question: We had a deal -- you broke it. You're going back to jail.
answer: Maybe. But you can't put every kid in that square in jail. They ain't goin' away, Joe.

question: Neither am I. I can wait them out. It won't be me that's hurt.
answer: You sure about that?

question: -- then I'll deal with that rabble in the street. He's crossing to a buzzer on his desk; Jack, thinking fast, snatches up a copy of the Newsies News.
answer: Ya got me, Joe -- but tell me one thing, willya? How'd ya like our paper -- nice printin', ain't it? Right off the presses of one of New York's greatest newspapers --

question: All the papers have an agreement... we print nothing about the newsies. Whose press did you use? It was Hearst, wasn't it...!
answer: Hearst? Nah, it was yo -- David quickly stops him, seeing the gleam in Pulitzer's eyes.

question: I knew it. Whoever helped you print this lying rag is trying to break the strike, get the jump on the rest of us. Well, you're going to expose this backstabber to the other owners -- in exchange, I'll call off the police.
answer: Not enough, Joe -- you gotta deal with our demands. Otherwise, our lips are sealed.

question: All right, all right -- just say the traitor's name. It's Hearst, isn't it? Say it! Say the name of the scoundrel whose press you used so I can make him the disgrace of the newspaper world! Say his name, damn you!
answer: We just wanna say, 'Thanks, Joe.' And Hearst and them other owners? Maybe they don't have to know. Depends.

question: Remember what I told ya -- first t'ing ya do in jail, you make friends with the rats, share what you got in common -- Hiya, Jack! My leg tells me the strike's over! *
answer: Crutchy -- I don't get it. What happened -- ?

question: Ya orta seen it, Jack -- he came chargin' into the Refuge wavin' his walkin' stick like a sword and he's leadin' this army of lawyers and cops and Snyder's hidin' in the patata bin --
answer: What're you talkin' about -- who come chargin' in?
